{"step_by_step_thinking": "The question is about a 72-year-old anthropologist with long-standing hypertension who has taken captopril and triamterene. Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that can cause hyperkalemia, which is elevated potassium levels in the blood. Triamterene is a diuretic that can also increase potassium levels. Given this information, it's likely that the abnormality on his laboratory results is hyperkalemia.", "answer_choice": "A"}
